div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p:
The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between
Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to
Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation
for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry
proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent
Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to
Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor,
Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to
Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque)
begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the
Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the
scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus
in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook
& Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY,
General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1907..

COCOA SLAVERY "One-fifth of all the cocok and chocolate we take is now produced for us by a form of black labour as truly slavery as anything on our own possessions before the Emancipation or on the plantations of the Southern States before the American Civil War." Thus Mı. H. W. Nevinson endeavours, in the course of a striking article in the September "Portnightly," to bring home to Englishmen their concern in the continuance of the Angola slave trade. A trade in slaves, beyond question, the contract labour system of the great | Portaguese province of sub-equatorial Africa

is proved to be. Mr. Nevinson recalls the first piteous evidence which he himself saw on the East and West road from the interior to Bengnella and Loanda - "innumerable shackles hanging on trees or strewn on the ground, skulls and bones lying on the path or in the bush close by, murdered men and women in every stage of decomposition, sometimes with the cleft of the axe visible in the skulls." Seized in dative fends, pawned to pay off ancestral or village debts, sold by Congo rebel soldiers, or raided over the frontier, such of the wretched victims as survive are disposed of either to the mainland | plantations - where they "work in gange, watched by drivers who urge them on with hippo whips or long pointed staves" - or to masters in the towns, where they do practically all the domestic and other work and are treated as absolute property, or to the cocoa islands of St. Thomas and Principe. About four thousand a year are exported to the islands, and, says Mr. Nevinson, "none ever come back."

This last is a peculiarly deadly fact. The Portuguese Government, which is as deeply pledged as we are ourselves to the abolition of slave-trading, says, and the Portuguese people no doubt believe, that a system of voluntary contract and repatriation is in effect. Mr. Nevinson declares that the contracts are fraudulent, and that they are regularly renewed without consent. "The climate," he adds, "in most parts, especially on Principe, is very unhealthy, the work is long and hard, the life entirely uninteresting and monotonous ; flogging with chicotte and palinatoria is common ; big dogs and sentries are kept to prevent the slaves running away ; if they are caught escaping in boats they are brought back and flogged ; if they escape to the forests as many do, the regulations provide for organized hunting parties. But as slavery goes, the treatment is not cruel, because cruelty is so expensive.” For every slave it costs from £10 to £40. The later evidence which Mr. Nevinson offers in support of the case set forth in his recent book appears to be unanswerable. His most important proposal is that no five-yene contract should be renewable unless the native has first returned to the mainland. He suggests, as a last hope, a boycott by British and other cocoa manufacturers ; but we suggest that it will be time enough to try private influence when the representations to the Portuguese Government which the Foreign Office has expressed its willingness to make, have proved useless.

div.p: Arrival of Yacht.
The American yacht “Athena" arrived in harbour yesterday evening. Egyptian University
The pupils of Daoud Salaama School have forwarded their ninth subscription towards the Egyptian University. Polloe Budget
During the last 24 hours 6 thefts, 23 misdemeanours and 8 contraventions have taken place in Cairo. Troop Parade.
The troops of the Egyptian Army will parade on the Observatory Ground at Abbassia, Cairo, on Thursday. Exhumation of Body
The public prosecutor, has ordered the exhumation of the body of Proof Bey, son of Oof Pasba, victim of the automobile accident which occurred last week, for a post-mortem examination. Suloide.

Aristides Joanides aged 30 years, employed in the Bank of Athens, married, and father of three children, threw himself into the Nile at Ghizeh. All search for his body has proved ineffectual. It is supposed that the deceased suffered from an incurable disease. The Olive Moor"

The S.S. "Olive Moor", which grounded the night before last, is still in the same position. A salvage steamer bas been telegraphed for and in the meantime every possible effort is being made to get her off the rocks. The weather this morning is more favourable and the cargo continues to be jettisoned with activity. Ship on Fire

The British steamer "Jura" of Liverpool, Captain Fellows, arrived on the 30th ult. from the far East, landed at Suez a Lascar seamen who was rescued from the British S.S. "Fortunatas" of "Melbourne," this vessel being abandoned in Lat. 5" 5' S. Long. 90" 54 E on the 9th August. The "Fortunatus” was on fire when the seaman was taken from the vessel, which was shortly seen to be completely gutted by the flames. The rest of the crew of the "Fortunatus" got away in the ship's boats before the 8.3. "Jura had been sighted. A Well-Deserved Lesson.

Yesterday morning a well-deserved lesson was given to an insolent European in the Rue de l'Ancienne Bourse for molesting a lady. For some time past the man had annoyed the lady by approaching her in the street and insulting her by his action. The lady complained to her husband, who arranged that she should walk down the street while he kept a short distance behind her. This the lady did and as usual the man accosted her, whereupon she struck him across the face, and the man had then to submit to probably the soundest thrashing from her husband to which he had ever been treated. A police officer intervened and arrested the man, who we trust will now have to suffer a severe punishment administered by the law. A Disagreeable Contretemps.

A very disagreeable contretemps occurred recently to the housekeeper of a prominent official in the Fayoum. The lady in question, of the mildest disposition, was met by the cavass of the Greek Consulate on her arrival at Cairo, and requested to accompany him to the Hellenic Consulate under suspicion of being concerned with events of * a questionable character, in Upper Egypt which happened recently. The charge was completely unfounded and an error of the grossest nature had been committed by the cavass. The lady made the most vigorous protest and insisted on being conveyed to the Continental Hotel where her identity could be established. This was done and further annoyance obviated, but it is to be hoped that similar difficulties will be rendered, impossible in the future.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: COLLAPSE OF BUILDINGS.

On the 27th ulto. Mr. J.H. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can yet give any information as to the number of buildings which have collapsed in Alexandria, Cairo and their environs, in the past 12 months, and the number of persons thereby killed and injured.
Sir E. Grey. The report which has been called for on the subject has not yet been received.

STUDENTS FOR EUROPE. Mr. John Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs if he can yet state the total amount of provision made by the Egyptian Government for sending students to Europe, and what prospect there is of increase in the number of qualified Egyptian teachers.

Sir E. Grey. The budget of the Egyptian Ministry of Education for 1908 has not yet been considered by the Council of Ministers and will not be finally settled till October. It is therefore impossible to say what the special credit alloted for the particular purpose will be.

I may state, however, that the Egyptian Ministry of Education is making arrangements with a view to sending this autumn 19 Egyptian students, a number not previously equalled, for training and further study in England, in addition to those who are already in this country undergoing special courses of instruction. It is hoped that all these Egyptian students, on the completion of their training, will enter the service of the Egyptian Government as teachers.
Mr. Rees asked whether it was right that the money of the Egyptian taxpayers should thus be expended in denationalising Egyptian students.

Sir E. Grey, replied that the object of the expenditure was to qualify Egyptian students to give the higher forms of instructions to their own countrymen, and that the expenditure of this kind was as proper in Egypt as elsewhere.
Mr. J. M. Robertson asked whether denationalising was not rather set up by the process of filling the Egyptian Civil Service with Englishmen. (Cheers.)
EDUCATION IN EGYPT.

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will obtain for the information of the House a classified list of professors who were employed by the Egyptian Government in teaching the sciences in Arabic at the date of the British occupation.

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will obtain for the information of the House a classified list of works, written in or translated into Arabic, upon scientific and technical subjects, and published in Arabic by the National Printing Press of Egypt, between the date of Mohamed Ali's accession, 1806, and that of the British occupation 1882.

Sir E. Grey. In answer to these questions, I must point out that I have already caused a great deal of extra, and in some cases laborious work on the part of officials in Egypt by asking for detailed information in reply to questions.

In this case I do not think it would be reasonable to ask them to make enquiries dating back to 1806. I do not know whether the information could be obtained, I do not suppose it could be obtained without much trouble, and when obtained, a list of persons and books could not be a guide to the value of the instruction given by them.

Mr. Robertson asked whether the required books could not be easily obtained from the catalogue of the Khedivial|Library; and whether such a list would not be a much better basis for conclusions as to the possibility of teaching the sciences in Arabic than the guesswork which had been hitherto presented to the House.
Sir E. Grey replied that without a knowledge of Arabic the House would not be able to draw any conclusion from such a list of books.

THE DENISHWAI SENTENCES Mr. Lehmann Asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he can state where the prisoners sentenced to penal servitude act Dinesh wai are carrying out their sentences, what is the nature of their labour, and if they are in irons: and whether if they had been tried under the ordinary law, such punishment as they are | now suffering could have been imposed on them.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey. My Rt. Hon friend has not the special information asked for on these points, but the sentences of the imprisonment are served in the same way as if they had been imposed by ordinary law.

Sir William Collins, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the decree of 1895, under which the Denishawi prisoners were tried, excludes all right of appeal against sentences ; and whether this also precludes the exercise of clemency, on the part of the Khedive in the case of capital sentences such as is provided for in the ordinary law of Egypt

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey - The text of the decree which the Hon. Members will find on p. 8 of Parliamentary Paper "Egypt No. 3 (1906)" states in the last paragraph of Article 4, that the sentences shall not be subject to appeal. If the Hon. Member will refer to p. 24 of the same Paper, he will see that the adoption of some procedure by which
the decisions of the Special Tribunal shall be I confirmed by some superior authority is under consideration, and the Tribunal will not be called into existence without some euch provision.

THE SPECIAL TRIBUNAL. Mr. Mackarness, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the deeree under which the special tribunal which tried the Denishwai prisoners was set up in any way prescribes what law is to be administered or what punishments may be inflicted and whether he can say if the law actually applied in the Denishwai trials was British, Egyptian or Mahommedan.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir B. Grey, My Rt. Hon. Friends can only refer to the Hon. Member to the text of the decree, which has been laid before Parliament, and to the observations of Lord Cromer as to the kind of punishments which should be in future prescribed if the Special Tribunal were again called into existence.

HAFEZ AWAD'S DEMANDS. Mr. MacNeill,- To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he has received an outline of views and wishes of the Egyptian nation as regards changes in the administration of Egypt which have already been sanctioned by the general assembly at its recent meeting, forwarded to him as Member of the House of Commons by M. A. Hafiz Awad, the proposals for the establishment of the constitution being based on the schemes put forward by Lord Dufferin in 1883 ; whether he is aware that the programme of the Egyptian national party embraces free and compulsory education in all schools, the conferring of legislative powers on the general assembly and legislative council in matters relating purely to Egyptian affairs, the gradual substitution of Egyptian for European officials and the transference of the criminal jurisdiction of the consular courts to mixed courts with subsidiary grants ; and whether, having regard to the fact that these proposals are authoritatively declared to constitute the minimum of the reforms necessary for Egyptian needs and aspirations the Government will take any, and, if so, what steps in the immediate future towards their concession.

Mr. Runciman, on behalf of Sir E. Grey replied :-My Rt. Hon. friend has received a communication of the nature described by the Hon. Member. But he has nothing to add to the statement of policy which he made in the debate on the Foreign Office Vote.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held yesterday morning at Alexandria when the following were approved :
1. The transfer of the French section from the Saaidieh to the Tewfikjeh School.
2. The opening of a credit of LE 19,500 to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration for the purchase of the dredger "St. Lawrence '' from the British Government.
3. The opening of a credit of L.E. 45,000 in excess of the credit allotted in the budget of the current year for the irrigation conversion works in Middle Egypt.
4. The opening of a supplementary credit of L.E. 6,737 for the strengthening of archæological monuments in Nubia.
3. The opening of a supplementary credit of LE. 5,000 for the completion of the Ghizeh reformatory.
6. The opening of a credit of L.E. 10,000 to the Public Health Department for fighting the bubonic and cattle plagues.
7. A credit of L. 2,976 for watering and scavenging new streets, at Rodah, Kasrel Aly, and Abbassieh
8. A credit of LE. 5,000 to the Public Works Department for helping the inhabitants of the Western Oasis to maintain their wells, to reopen old wells and dig new ones.
9. A credit of LE. 4,800 for the construction of barracks at Abbassieh.
10. The exemption of the Asile de Vieillards at Alexandria from the registration fee on a parcel of land purchased at Moharram Bey for the erection of a new Home.
11. An ordinance regulating the introduction and carriage of arms into Sudan.
12. The construction of five bridges over canals in Assonan province.
13. Declaration of public utility, the erection of houses for the railway staff at The elBaroud and other minor public works.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS
div.p: UPPER EGYPT MAIN LINE.

The double line from Maghaga to Minieh was opened on Sunday. This event marks another advance in the history of the State Railways including the entire modification of Etsa, Samallout, Klossana Mattai, Moaddah and Aba-el-Wakf stations also a new station at El Burquier between Esta and Minieh, a new deviation from kil. 178 to kil. 181 on which is the new Maghaga station goods yard and a new connection with the Sucreries Railways. The above work has been actively pushed ahead since the beginning of this year.

div.head: THE YEMEN SITUATION.
div.p: UOUSA
WORSE THAN EVER
(From OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)

Aden, August 26. That the military situation in Yemen is worse than ever is evidenced by the outbreaks among the Turkish troops in the Yemen, which have become so frequent of late us to be unparalleled in the history of the Yemen campaign, and for which the treatment received | by the troops, and their arrears of pay is solely responsible. Advice received from Yemen states that a mutiny has broken out among the troops in Amran, which lies about three days from Sana. These troops are under the command of Ydssif Pasha, and about 3000 of them under arins have left Amran and proceeded to Hodeida, and from there they want to embark for their homes. They have now reached Manakha, and on their way from Amran they have given trouble to the people. * A telegraphic message was dispatched from Sanaa to Hodeidah informing the authorities to be on the lookout. Much apprehension is entertained at Hodeidah of coming trouble.

div.head: WEATHER DURING AUGUST.
div.p: We have received from the Survey Department the following report on the weather in Egypt and the Sudan during August 1907

The normal meteorological conditions in August are that a region of high pressure lies over the western Mediterranean and Northwest Africa, and in southern Africa in the neighbourhood of lat. 20°8. From these regions there is a steady gradient towards the Indian region of low pressure to the east of the Persian gulf. These conditions remain very constant giving steady breezes and clear skies as far as Dongola. South of this, southerly winds occur with frequent thunderstorms and rain.
During the past month pressure was in moderate excess in Egypt, and in large excess in Sudan. Temperature was above normal | in Egypt reaching 39° C at Helwan and 48 C
in Aswan, but in Sudan it was much below the average, the mean of the month near Khartoum, Dueim and Wad Medani being more than 2 below the pormal.

The distribution of the rainfall is remarkable ; at Khartoum, Kassala and Wad Medapi the amount recorded was in excess of the average by 144, 127 and 57 mm. respectively, while numerous washouts on the railways were reported.

In Eritrea rainfall at Adi Ugri was also in slight excess. In Abyssinia at Addis Ababa however there was a deficiency of 14 % in the first half of the month, and except for very heavy rainfall about the 20th which caused a large flood wave in both the Blue Nile and the Atbara there has not been a sustained improvement.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING
div.p: The Summary Court of Justice, Alexandria, has ordered the Boarse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited to pay indemnities to those employés who were dismissed without notice sums varying between three and four months' worth of their salaries.

div.head: TO KHARTOUM BY MOTOR
div.p: fbe ``Daily Mail '' reports that Mr. Bentley and Mr. Wells, two young Englishmen, who left Djibouti at the beginning of the month on an 18-h.p. car in an attempt to reach Khartoum, successfully crossed from Djibouti to Zeila. They left the latter place on Friday week for Dire Daoud, the present railhead, travelling via | Adagalla. Then they proceed to Addis Ababa, the capital of Abyssinia.
The journey has been one of immense difficulty, owing both to the sand of the desert and the mountainous district traversed, but the car has run splendidly.

div.head: LEMNOS AND EGYPT.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Liner "Osmanieh" will specially call on her way back from Constantinople at the island of Lemnos on the 7th September, where a considerable number of passengers will embark for Alexandria.
The majority of the Lemnos inhabitants are established in Egypt, and yearly many hundred pass their summer in that island which of late has become quite fashionable.
The island possesses hot mineral water baths, situated about 4 miles out of the town, and same are said to contain soda and magnesia and are proved to be excellent for indigestion, rheumatism
Lemnos is as well famous for partridge and | pigeon shooting, practically all the year round,

with the exception of the months of May, June, and July when shooting is prohibited. Owing to the fact that there is only one direct line of steamers from Lemnos to Alexandria of rather small tonnage, almost every season the visitors arrange for a liner to call and bring them back to Egypt.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The s.s. "Egyptian Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the end inet., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Friday.

div.head: AUSVIIKUT ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)

London, August 24. Major and Brevet Colonel G. F. Milne, D.8.O., commanding the 59th Battery Royal Field Artillery, Brighton, has been selected for a horse artillery Jacket," and has been placed under orders to proceed to Cairo to take up the command of the "U" Battery, R.H.A. Lieutenant Colonel Milne is a distinguished officer of the Royal Regiment. He obtained his first commission in 1885, was promoted captain in 1895, major in 1900, brevet Lieutenant colonel in 1902, and brevet colonel last year. His first active service experience was in the Nile Expedition, 1898, when he shared in the battle of Khartoum, Egyptian medal with clasp, (British medal) and he was on the staff during the South African War, 1899-1902, including the operations in the Orange Free State, the actions of Paardeberg, Poplar Grove, Vet River, and Zand River ; operations in the Transvaal, the actions of Johannesburg, Pretoria and Diamond Hill; and the operations generally in Cape Colony, Orange River Colony and the Transvaal down to the close of the war (mentioned in despatches, D.8.0., brevet lieutenant colonel, Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).
Captain W. H. Higginson, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been placed on duty with the draft for the 21st Battalion, at Alexandria, Egypt
The 1st Battalion Fusiliers, Malta, lately in Egypt, will leave that garrison on the 27th November next for Karachi, per the 8.8.
Dongola, and on arrival there will proceed to | Meerut and subsequently to Chakrata.

The Temeraire, which has just taken the water at Devonport, is the third of the Dreadnoughts. She is supposed to be an improvement on the original and the improved men's affected in her construction are being jealously guarded from the public. Very | little is known of her beyond that she measures 490 feet in length, has a beam of | 82 feet, and will have a displacement of | 18,400 tons when completed. She will be turbine engined, with an energy of 28,999 h.p., will be protected on the waterline by Ja 12 inch hardened steel belt along her entire length and will carry an armament of ten 12 inch 56 ton guns, and a number of smaller gans, of which the 7.5 will form a proportion. Her estimated speed is 21 knots. A lot of the details published about her are mere conjectures.
It is understood that the issue of the new naval uniform will be commenced on the 1st January next. The new caps, however, will not be issued until the stock now in hand is further reduced.

div.head: LOST LINK WITH NAPOLEON.
div.p: Probably few people, on reading the announcement of the death at Cape Town of Commissary General of Ordnance (retired) George Brooks Bonnett, formerly Chief Staff Paymaster of the Cape command, were aware of the fact that with him died the last remaining person who had seen the great Na poleon in the flesh. He was, says the "City | Press' ', the second son of the late Captain James Bennett, of the East India Company's service, and that officer was on duty at St. Helena at the time of the arrival there of Napoleon. Young George Bennett spent his childhood on the island, and had many opportunities of seeing the famous captive there, and was able in after-life to relate interesting anecdotes as to his early impressions and experiences. He came to England for his education, and when later, as a young officer, he was proceeding to the Cape, the ship he was in arrived at St. Helena at the time of the translation of the late Emperor's remains from the place of burial on the island to the French warship sent by King Louis Philippe to convey them to France. Commissary Bennet never returned to England, for, having served on the Cape command until he retired under the age conditions, he bought a charming house at Hof Street, near Cape Town, and spent his remaining days there. He had, therefore, no opportunities of being connected with the City, but his father, Captain Bennett, was admitted a Freeman in March, 1808, and his grandfather, Thomas Bennett, was a "Citizen and Joiner." Commissary Bennett was ninety-one years of age.

div.head: THE NEW TESTAMENT.*
div.p: This work consists of five lectures first published in "The Expository Times' ' (Oet. 1906 April 1907) and translated from the German by L.R.M. Strachan, M.A. Dr. Deissmann deals with the question of the discoveries of archaeologists in relation to Primitive Christianity. Whilst admitting the importance of the literary materials, he points out that these are only fragmentary, and protests against over estimating the worth of the purely literary evidence. The importance of the non-literary evidence, i.e. the innumerable texts on stone, metal, papyrus, | wood or clay has only been made accessible during recent years, and the author states that the recognition of their importance for the historical understanding of Primitive Chris tienity is still by no means general.
*Now Light on the New Testament, by Dr. A. Deinemann. T. and T. Qark, Edinburgh /

div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, is expected at Cairo on Sunday morning.se
General Bellook is leaving next week for Cyprus to inspect the troops of that island. He will be accompanied by Lieutenant Fraser.

div.head: HORSESHOE DINNER.
div.p: As reported in our issue of yesterday the English jockeys of the Alexandria Sporting Club and several of their friends met at dinner on Saturday night at the Abbey Hotel under the presidency of Mr. N. Smith and with Mr. Taylor as vice-chairman This meeting, the first of what is to become an annual event, was a true sportsman's meeting, and it would have been gratifying to the owners of the stables to witness the friendship and bonne camaraderie existing between the sporting rivals who ride their horses for victory, and many of whom have attained it with brilliant.

As an introduction to the dinner the toast of the King and Constitution was drunk, and after that evidence of loyalty which is one of the most prominent characteristics of every true sportsman, the meeting settled down to dispose of as excellent a menn as has ever graced a table. With the advent of dessert the toast of the Guests was proposed by Mr. Nanny who coupled with it the names of Mr. Jenkins and Mr. Whiteside, from whose dinners in previous years the idea of instituting an annual horseshoe dinner originated. Mr. Whiteside responded and after the toast had been drunk with hearty acclamation, Mr. Stillwel! followed by a song. Mr. Taylor then proposed Sport, which was replied to by Mr. Jenkins, and the programme was next varied by a violin solo most sympathetically rendered by Mr. Smith. The Army and Navy, proposed by Mr.Clements, was the next tonat, and this was replied to by Mr. Murphy, and Mr. Macgregor then proposed a cordial toast to the Press which was responded to by Mr. Swanson, The toast of Commerce was given by Mr. Husky and responded to by Mr. Denman, and a special toast to Mr. Bonser as the oldest jockey of Alexandria, proposed by Mr. Taylor, was then received with "For he's a jolly good fellow." Mr. Wiloooks gave us the toast of Harmony, which indeed was the tone of the evening's meeting. Among those who contributed to the evening's enjoyment with songs were Mr. Jenkins, Mr. Bonser, Mr. Sidey, Mr. Galley, Mr. Wallacker, and Mr. Rance who recited "the Kissing Cup" from the well-known play "Run-a-look."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA-BOURSE.
div.p: TA (Aujourd'hui à 11h. 1/2 a.m.).

Bien que le marché ait présenté ce matin un aspect assez animé, les transactions ont ét presque nalles. Bexplication de ces faits en apparence contradictoires se trouve dans l'a bondance des ordres et l'absence des contre parties. Aussi les fluctuations, en grande par tie nominales, n'ont-elles qu'une importance re lative ; elles sont d'ailleurs peu considérables S'il faut signaler parmi les valeurs celles qu ont le plus attiré l'attention, nous dirons que en sont principalement les petites, entre autres la Hooker, TUnited et la Delta Land
La' Ramleh hausse de 4 5/8 à 4 3/4 et les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 143 144. Les Dividendes sont toujours l'objet d'une demande active provenant de Bruxelles.
En reprise aussi la Daïra de 12 1/2 à 12 5/8, la Banque d'Orient de 117 & 118 1/2 et l'O bligation Crédit Foncier de 302 à 302 1/2 l'an cienne et de 255 à 255 1/2 la nouvelle.
Les Lots Tares fléchissent, au contraire, de 159 à 158, la Deferred Delta de 9 à 8 3/4, et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/8 à 4 1/16.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, les Markets s'avancent de 27 à 27/6, la Cassa di Sconto de 42 à 44, la Building Lands de 91/4 à 2 5/16, et l'Helouan de 7/32 à 1/4, tandis que le Comptoir revient de 2 19/32 à 2 9/16, l'Allotment de 2 1/2 à 2 3/8 l'action et de 65 à 62 la part de fondateur, la fondateur United de 2 à 1 7/8.

Une vente aux enchères publiques demandée par un courtier pour compte d'un de ses clients a donné les résultats suivants : 25 actions Allotment à 2 3/8 et 50 parts de fondateur à 62 P.T., 50 actions United à 3/8 et 4 parts de fondateur à 1 29/32, 50 Karam à 3/8, 50 Delta Land & 1 29/32, 50 Estates à 43/64, 50 Salt and Soda anciennes à 18/74 et 11 nouvelles à 17, 25 Building Lands à 2 5/16 et 150 New Egyptian à 14/

En ce qui concerne la tendance, il serait bien difficile de la définir. Il n'y en a pas. On a vagnement l'impression qu'il doit y avoir une reprise en automne, mais tant de circonstances exceptionnelles barrent la route à un mouvement hausgier qu'on reste indécis. Tont dépend de l'aisance monétaire et il est clair que rien ne nous la fait prévoir pour le moment. Les tribunaux regorgent de protêts. Il y a cependant en faveur de l'Egypte et de notre marché une brillante récolte en perspective. Cela suffira-t-il pour ramener ici la circulation d'or nécessaire !

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
div.p: THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
CASABLANCA, September 2. The reconnoitering party yesterday directed their efforts to the Sonth and routed a large band of Moorish horsemen. (Havas)
PARIS, September 2. The Council of Ministers conferred in the evening upon the contingencies connected with Morocco
(Havas)
HAFEZ AWAD'S PROGRAMME.
ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF RECEIPT.
LONDON, September 3. The Foreign Office has written to Hafiz Award acknowledging receipt of his programme for the reform of the administration of Egypt, emanating from the Egyptian National Party,
(Reuter)
FLORIO CUP RACE.
BARON DE MARTINO KILLED.
speed.
BRESCIA, September 2. The Italian, Cagno, has won the cuptor
(Havas)
Rome, September 2 A series of accidents occurred at the motor race for the Florio Cup at Brescia. Baron De Martino was killed.
TROUBLE IN PERSIA.
THE PREMIER ASSASSINATED.
INCREASE OF LAWLESSNESS.

London, September 2. The “Daily Mail '' learns from Tehran that five shots were fired at the Premier : he died on the spot. A soldier and a Cossack were also killed and a deputy wounded. One of the assailants has committed suicide and another has been arrested : the rest have escaped. The British and Russian Ministers have sent to the Shah their condolences. Lawlessness is increasing in the country districts.
The newspapers welcome the Anglo-Russian agreement as further securing peace throughout the world, though it in nowise implies an entente like the Anglo-French one.

The “Standard” learns from St Petersburg that former spheres of activity in Persia have been abolished, Russia making concessions whereby Northern Persia is opened to British commercial enterprises and Great Britain making similar concessions in Southern Persia. (R.)

TEHERAN, September 2. The Premier's assassin was a money changer named Abbasali from Baku. Letters found on his body and on that of his accomplice show that they acted on orders from a revolutionary committee at Baku.
RETURN OF MORINGA.
BERLIN, September 2. It is officially stated that Moringa has returned to Cape territory with 70 of his followers and has offered to surrender., (R.)
ANCHOR STROKE ABOLISHED.
London, September 2. At a special meeting of the Billiard Association it was decided to abolish the anchor stroke.
(Reuter)
OBITUARY.
LONDON, September 2. Obituary. Mr. David Mac Iver, M.P. (Renter)
LUCERNE, September 2. Colonel Sir Augustus Charles Frederick Fitzgeorge, eldest son of H.R.H. the late Duke of Cambridge, has died here. (Reuter

ANTWERP, September 2. An extension of the dockers' strike here has been proceeding for many weeks, disorganising shipping and causing serious disturbances and much damage to property : many English strike-breakers have been injured. (Reuter)
SULTAN'S ACCESSION
ANNIVERSARY.
The Hague, September 2. Turkan Pasha held a reception on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the Sultan.
(Havas)
COAL STRIKE AT ANVERS.
.. ANVERS, September 2. The workmen connected with the coal and metal works have struck. Quarrels have taken place.
(Havas)
SCOTCH RAILWAY
COLLISION.
EDINBURGH, September 2, Twenty passengers have been injured in a railway collision at Bo'ness, (Reuter)
THE UNVEILED EAST.

Of the three books under review, the "Spectator” remarks that Miss Fisher's is merely the diary of an adventurous lady who travelled in the inland parts of Japan, and has given us a somewhat gushing impressionist account of what she saw, illustrated by some good photographs. But the other two are works with the most serious import, which well deserve the attention of all interested in fo reign affairs. Sir Henry Colvile's purpose is best stated in his own words: "The union of Japan and England is indeed one made in Heaven." He is a fervent admirer of the Japanese; he has also a patriotic understanding of the merits of his countrymen; and he thinks that the allies are suited to meet

each other's wants. The book is largely com1 piled from other works, for Sir Henry has been a most diligent student of the literature on the subject. He thinks, that we should have Japanese Professors of Morality in our schools to teach our sons how to serve their country, and that we should learn from Japan how to spend our wealth to the best propose. Japan has great spiritual lessons to teach us, he argues, while we in turn can assíst her with our worldly wisdom. He will listen to no criticisms on his idol. The artificial barriers set up between her and Britain are due to the deliberate misrepre. sensations of rivals and the prejudice and ignorance of missionaries." "The Shanghai merchant," he says, “who has exiled himself for years, buoyed up by the hope that by a certain period, whose length he has calculated to a nicety,' he will have made a fortune on which he can retire, may well be excused for the disappointment and rage with which he views the prospect of his toil being almost indefinitely prolonged by Japan's commercial success." There is no "yellow peril," but there is a substantial "Teuton terror”; it is Germany who is suffering mainly from Japan, and it is Germany who invents all the libels. Sir Henry Colvile's book, in spite of much dubious scientific and philosophical speculation, is full | of interest and value. He states one side of
the case with enthusiasm and force ; but his argument is bound to leave the reader conscious that there must be another view of the question.

Mr. McKenzie in his remarkable work provides that other view. We call it "remarkable," for, though the book is full of faults of manner, including an undue sentimentality, and of arrangement, including constant repeti

w) The Unveiled East." By F. A. MeKenzie London: Hutchinson and Co. (12s. net.) - (2) The Allier," By Major General Sir Henry Colvile, K.P.M.G. Same publishers. [10s.net.(3) "A Woman Alone in the Heart of Japan." B, Gertaude Adams Fisher. London : Bisley's. [78. 6d. net.)
tion, yet it has the great merit of stating ade I quately a point of view which has hitherto been confined to the conversation of certain Par

East residents. If Mr. McKenzie is right, the peculiar civilisation of Japan, from which Sir Henry Colvile thinks such profound lessons are to be drawn for English practice, is all but gone. If he is right, so far from being a desirable ally, Japan is by far our most formidable rival. Japan, he says in effect, can only realise her ambitions at the expense of British interests. This would be fair enough were it not that, according to him, Japanese methods are themselves a menace to civilisation. "I believe, reluctantly and against my own personal inclinations, that the methods of expansion adopted by Japan must, if not modified, bring. disturbance to world peace.” Here is his thesis set out in his first chapter :
"That which men yesterday believed Russia to be in the Far East, Japan now is. Proclaim|ing with all possible publicity her adherence

to the doctrine of the 'open door,' she has adopted a policy of national preference and exclusive privilege ; nominally standing for the integrity of China, she is maturing plans that can have no purpose if they do not involve the passing of large parts of Chinese territory into Japanese hands. She does not threaten India from the north by the advance of armies, but her teachers are stirring up unrest among some of the Indian peoples, and her official agents have for nearly two years been at work on a great trade campaign there directly aimed at Lancashire's most profitable market."

A good deal of this we must take for granted. If Japan is to become a great commercial people, she must do it partly at the expense of other commercial peoples. The real point is as to the reasonableness and fairness of the methods employed. "What proof does Mr. McKenzie offer of his serious indictment ? Japan, he says, is working along three lines, territorial expansion, increased fighting-power, and an aggressive commercial campaign. We have no space to give the details of his evidence, and can only indicate the general argument. As to the first, the great instances are Korea and Manchuria. If Mr. McKenzie is correct, Japan has played a very doubtful part in Korea. Entering the country originally as friend and protector, she has acquired supreme power by devious methods, and has filled all the best posts with her countrymen. Korean nationalism has protested, but Japan has been beforehand and stifled the protests. We witnessed some such ineffectual effort the other day at the Hague Conference, when Korea applied in vain to be recognised as a separate Power. Critics might find in all this parallel to the British occupation of Egypt; but Mr. McKenzie is ready with an answer. The Japanese régime in Korea is not only arbitrary, it is highly inefficient. Property is no safer, the wheels of government run, no smoother, than in the old days. The same sight is to be seen in Manchuria, which Japan is flooding with her citizens, many of them of an undesirable class. As to the second line of policy, Mr. MacKenzie instances the enormous expenditure on the Japanese Army and Navy. In a few years the Army will be doubled, the fighting-power of the Navy more than doubled. But the third is the most striking. The Japanese Government was constituted itself into one vast Board of Trade. The first necessity of Japan is wealth, and she wishes to get it quickly. Mr. MacKenzie has a great deal to say about Japanese commercial morality, which he does not rate high. The country is enormously taxed to provide funds for capital expenditure on new industries. The State is busy creating monopolies, such as the tobacco industry. It is subsidising new railways and shipping lines, and new industries like cotton-spinning. There are no Factory Acts, so children from the age of eight are found at the works. Wherever, as is shown in Manchuria, Japanese authority is supreme, the door is closed against foreign competition. There is a vast stream of emigration, but no Japanese is ever naturalised abroad, and they are always ready to return when their Sovereign calls them. It is in China where this commercial policy is seen most clearly. China is a mine of untouched wealth, and Japan has resolved to have the exploitation 1 of it solely in her own hands.

But China is by no means of the same opinion. Mr. McKenzie's most interesting chapters concern that new China which had been born within the last decade, He draws a full-length portrait of Yuan-Shih Kai, the great Viceroy of Chi-li, to whom the reform movement is mainly due. A new Army har been created, the Departments have been purged of incompetent officials, and there is desire everywhere, not only for China for the Chinese, but for the frank acceptance a Western civilisation. China is awake to her danger. She sees that unless she sets her house in order she will pass under the controla Japan. She has no anti-foreign feeling, according to Mr. McKenzie, but she is very strong anti-Japanese. The wise course for Britain, h says, is to aid China in her new development
She needs a friend among the Great Power -, and our interest demands that that friend
should be Britain. For Japanese success will b won at our expense as well as at that of China

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN SALAD.
div.p: My fountain pen occasionally bubbles and overflows in its anxiety to get to work, and to-night is particularly restive, but I must restrain its ardour and confine its periods to a few remarks upon Alexandria in general, and its places of amusement in particular. I write in the plural, but they appear to me singularly lacking in quantity and quality. Most of them are trashy, many are not to be mentioned in letters home, and the remainder have been captured by the cinematograph fiend, a Weird spirit of light and darkness that is mak
ing fearsome strides in public favour. But it Jis poor relaxation after arduous pursuit of the

cotton worm, and engrossing worship of the god get-rich-quick, which is Alexandria's own particular Baal, when we need to calm our financial coverings by watching someone else doing the work, and doing it well. True we have a new Theatre and the Zizinis, but the former is in a semi-finished stage, and the latter only occasionally opens its gloomy portals to heavy opera. So we await some enterprising manager who will give us somewhere to go, and make it come again. Speaking of cinematography, it is a mystery where those weird and wondrous scenes come from. But it seems this fiend can command anything and all things in its compilation of exciting Jinterest. The "Globe" endeavours to solve the mystery by reporting a case of some hamane individuals who bought two lions and after eluding authorities betook themselves to an island near Copenhagen, and organized a sort of lion hunt. The animals were let loose while someone ground out films from a camera. Considerable damage was done and the photo grinder nearly munched up before the lions were shot. But tell me, which were the beasts 1 Methinks that the fiend's hour has not yet come; soon we shall have cinemagraphs in every home and the national eyesight will deteriorate with watching filmy scenes.

The Britisher takes his pleasure seriously, and toils unceasingly after the elusive ball, to the wonder of the locals and the envy of my personal self. I say envy because I don't know how they do it, and with the thermometer dane. ing about in the upper regions deem it wiser to survey the denizens of the Sporting Club from the breezier heights of the electric car.
Should there be a craving for a milder form of exercise, and one feel worked up to the I pitch of a long "stretcher" there is practically

no opportunity to indulge, for "walks” are few and far between and the exercise of walking itself is no light matter in hot countries. Indeed, in these days of easy locomotion the man with the knapsack is becoming like the dodo, extinet. Certainly we have a long promenade in

this town, the much discussed sea wall, but it | is more or less of a white elephant at present, and wholly given over to ne'er-do-wells and bread vendors, with an occasional eastern disciple of Isaac Walton scorching in the sun and patiently catching nothing. I understand the Municipality is going to continue the sea
tront to some considerable distance. They are el no doubt wise in their generation but I am in

clined to ask "why ?" A spirit of vandalism has already painted the old Roman tower a gaudy yellow and is evidently going to further develop itself in wiping out the many picturesque spots along the beach. The one sight of Alexandria to me is the arm of the old city stretching into the sea, and gazing there at night, one can be deluded into thinking they are in an eastern town, and wax sentimental or poetical as the spirit moves. That too is soon to be blotted out with modern buildings.
Vandalism can rank among one of the | Arts. There is something so quiet and insidious in its methods, so thorough and com
plete in its work. Not a very pleasant art, Tbgt one that is growing to such a point of e perfection that soon we shall have only our
histories to remind us of a past. It is the
arch-enemy of time and toys with the pleading savant and laughs with the student.
It is the 'Juggernaut car of the jerrybuild
er and its destructive progress is accelerated in an age which recognises no age but
its own. Here in Egypt it is particularly a rampant, finds quite a happy hunting ground me for its rambles, and for years it is has roped and supported among the tombs and an
ancient cities, and ere long will cart off the Pyramids for building stone, and the sight

will be marked with a café. me The ancient built and lived for the future, of but the modern.--I hardly think be knows er himself! Some times during my wandering se in Boulevard Ramleh I have tried to wax of historical, to imagine the Museum still in d. existence, to mark the spot where Hypatia ly once dispensed philosophy to her students me to mentally transform the arabes into t.chariots and to clothe the passers by with
togas and flowing robes. But it won't do, mod ndern buildings and streets have no tratti be with imagination.

Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique of il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés: .
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 17. Septembre 1907.

AVIS

Le 3 Septembre 1907 de 9 h. a.m. à 1 h. p.m. la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux enchères publiques près du Port (Port Rosette) d'une quantité de 10000 m3 environ de pierres provenant de ladite démolition, ainsi que d'une quantité de fenêtres, vieux bois. | Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 2 à 100 m3

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication,

Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de Dix (10) jours sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et sous perte du dépôt de 10%
La Municipalité est libre de ne pas donner suite à l'adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts. Alexandrie, le 27 Août 1907.
Le Vice-Président, 30845-9-3 (Signé) DR. SCHIESS.
